question: What is an HTTP verb?

incorrect_answers: An identifier that specifies if the request action will return or send data to and from the client

question: What is the difference between the XMLHttpRequest getResponseHeader and getAllResponseHeaders methods?
correct_answer: The getResponseHeader method returns the value of the specified header name as a string parameter, whereas getAllResponseHeaders returns all headers.
incorrect_answers: The getResponseHeader method returns the value of the specified header by its index number, whereas getAllResponseHeaders returns all headers.
The getResponseHeader method returns the matching header specified as a parameter, whereas getAllResponseHeaders returns all custom headers.
The getResponseHeader method returns the first response header as a string, whereas getAllResponseHeaders returns all headers.

question:

GET api/get_users
This application should expose an API adhering to the RESTful architectural style. What is the issue ?
correct_answer: The URI should not contain the HTTP verb.
incorrect_answers: The URI should not contain a pluralized noun.

question: How can you prefix all routes in an Express application with api?
correct_answer:
const router = express.Router();

router.get('/', (req, res) => {

 res.send('Hello!');

});

app.use('/api/', router);
incorrect_answers:
app.get('/api', (req, res) => {

 res.send('Hello!');

});

const router = express.Router();

app.get('/', (req, res) => {

 res.send('Hello!');

});

app.use('/api/', router);

const router = express.Router('api');

router.get('/', (req, res) => {

 res.send('Hello!');

});

question: What is the purpose of the XMLHttpRequest (XHR) object?

incorrect_answers: To serialize and deserialize XML objects when performing HTTP requests

incorrect_answers: Store timestamps in the headers of the requests.

question: How would you create and use a custom exception middleware in Express?
correct_answer:
app.use(function (err, req, res, next) {

 res.status(500).json({

  status: 500,

  message: 'Custom Error',

 });

});
incorrect_answers:
app.useMiddleware(function (err, req, res, next) {

 res.status(500).json({

  status: 500,

  message: 'Custom Error',

 });

});

app.use(function (req, res, err) {

 res.status(500).json({

  status: 500,

  message: 'Custom Error',

 });

});

app.useError(function (req) {

 res.status(500).json({

  status: 500,

  message: 'Custom Error',

 });

});

question: What is Node.js?

incorrect_answers: A package that is used to access the file system of a web server

A library that can be used to run JavaScript code server-side

question:
You need to create an API method that will be used for retrieving a list of items; however, when testing the code below, you only receive the first item.

const express = require('express');

const app = express();

app.get('/', (req, res) => {

 res.send(

   { id: 123, name: 'item1' },

   { id: 234, name: 'item2' },

   { id: 345, name: 'item3' }

  );

});

What changes would you make to solve this?
correct_answer: The items to be sent need to be part of a JavaScript array.
incorrect_answers: The toList() method should be called after send.
The sendItems method should be used instead.
The items to be sent should be included in an object with an array property.

question: You want to upload a large file to the server via Fetch API, but you only want to do so if the connection is fast. To avoid a timeout, you will cancel the request if it hasn't succeeded in 2 seconds, but there is no explicit functionality to do so in the Fetch API. How can you proceed?
correct_answer: Use an AbortController with setTimeout.
incorrect_answers: Use an UploadController with setInterval.
Use an UploadController with setTimeout.
Use an AbortController with setInterval.

question: You are using the Web Storage API in your app to save data in the browser. You decide to use the session storage mechanism for all of the data. What will happen when the browser is closed?
correct_answer: Data is lost
incorrect_answers: Data is persisted on the client

question:

 res.status(204);

});

What is the issue with this implementation?

incorrect_answers: The Express delete method does not return any status code.
The status returned from an HTTP DELETE operation should be 200.
The Express delete method does not receive an object id as a parameter.

question:

router.delete('/:id', (req, res) => {

 deleteItem(req.body);

 res.status(204); 

});

What is the issue?
correct_answer: An HTTP DELETE request cannot use the req.body.
incorrect_answers: An HTTP DELETE request does not have an id parameter.
The returned status is not appropriate for a DELETE request.

question:
You are debugging the API endpoint below that uses Node.js and Express. The request hangs and times out while testing an HTTP PUT request. What could be the problem?

// ...

router.put('/:id', (req, res) => {

 const itemToUpdate = getItemById(req.params.id);

 if (itemToUpdate) {

  updateItem(req.body, req.params.id);

 } else {

  res.status(404).send();

 }

});

// ...
correct_answer: The HTTP 200 response status is not returned.
incorrect_answers: The id value for the PUT request is stored in req.id and not req.params.
The HTTP 404 response status should be an HTTP 400.
You used status() instead of the sendStatus() method.

question: You have a cached response from a REST API call. You decide to make a fresh call and cache the new response instead. How should you do this, ensuring that the previously cached response is overwritten?

incorrect_answers: Use cache.replace(url, response) to make a new request to the REST API and store the response.

question:
The code below uses the XMLHttpRequest object to retrieve data:

function getData() {

  const url = 'http://localhost:5000/api';

  let req = new XMLHttpRequest();

  req.onreadystatechange = function () {

    if (this.readyState === XMLHttpRequest.DONE && this.status == 200) {

      let response = JSON.parse(this.response);

      alert(response);

    }

  };

  req.send();

}

The request fails to execute. How can you solve this issue?
correct_answer: Call the open() method before send().
incorrect_answers: The XMLHttpRequest constructor should receive the url as a parameter.
Call the open() method after send().
The send() method should receive url as a parameter.

incorrect_answers: The second URL will be returned as a match.

question: What is the difference between the status message and the response body when handling error responses from a JSON REST API endpoint?
correct_answer: The status message contains the HTTP status description. The response body contains a JSON object representing the error(s).
incorrect_answers: The status message contains the HTTP status code. The response body contains a message describing any error(s).

question:
How will you extend the following code snippet to incorporate a Claims store, assuming you have a Mongo collection 'Claims' set up as your data store?

app.get('/authorize', (req, res) => {

  const { username, password } = req.body;

  const user = verifyAndGetUser(username, password);

  const token = jwt.sign(user, privateKey, { expiresIn: '1h' });

  res.send(token);

});
correct_answer:
const user = verifyAndGetUser(username, password);

const userClaims = db.claims.findOne({ userId: user.id });

const token = jwt.sign(userClaims, privateKey, { expiresIn: '1h' });
incorrect_answers:
const userClaims = db.claims.findOne({ username });

const token = jwt.sign(userClaims, privateKey, { expiresIn: '1h' });

const user = verifyAndGetUser(username, password);

const claims = db.claims.insert(user);

const token = jwt.sign(claims, privateKey, { expiresIn: '1h' });

const user = db.claims.findOne({ username });

if (password !== user.password) {

  res.status(401).send();

} else {

  const token = jwt.sign(userClaims, privateKey, { expiresIn: '1h' });

}

question: You are working on a client-side implementation of a form for an item on an e-commerce site. One of the inputs on this form is a file. You want to place the input file on an area of the site that is not the form itself. How can you still associate the file with the form?
